question: I don't...
answer: Ever pick your feet in Poughkeepsie?

question: What?
answer: Did you ever pick your feet in Poughkeepsie?

question: I don't know what you're talkin' about.
answer: Were you ever in Poughkeepsie?

question: No... yeah...
answer: Did you ever sit on the edge of the bed, take off your socks and stick your fingers between your toes?

question: Man, I'm clean.
answer: You made three sales to your roaches back there. We had to chase you through all this shit and you tell me you're clean?

question: You put a shiv in my partner. Know what that means? All winter I gotta listen to him gripe about his bowling scores. Now I'm gonna bust your ass for those three bags - then I'm gonna nail you for pickin' your feet in Poughkeepsie. Havin' trouble? You're a dumb guinea.
answer: How'd I know he had a knife.

question: Never trust a nigger.
answer: He coulda been white.

question: Never trust anybody. You goin' sick?
answer: Not a chance.

question: Let's popeye around the Chez for a half hour, catch the end of the show and a couple drinks.
answer: Some other time Jimmy, I'm beat.

question: Come on -- one drink. Whatta you say?
answer: Drink this.

question: Who is that guy?
answer: Policy man in Queens.

question: What about the last of the big-time spenders. You make him?
answer: No, you?

question: Hunh-uh. Check the bread. He spreads it like the Russians are in Jersey.
answer: He probably sells insurance. Owns a chicken farm in Hackensack.

question: Whatta you say we wait and give him a tail?
answer: Give who a tail?

question: The greaser with the blonde.
answer: What for -- you wanna play Hide the Salami with his old lady?

question: Come on -- just for fun -- Monica? Who's Monica?
answer: A and A, that's all you're interested in -- Arrests and Ass.

question: Cloudy, I'll lay odds he takes us to Little Italy.
answer: I'm telling you, Popeye, he owns a bagel mine in the Bronx.

question: En prolongeant les quais d'une trentaine de mtres on pourra recevoir des units d'une cargaison de 500 tonnes. Ca fera environ 10 hommes de plus par quipe. Quelle importance. Ce qui compte pour moi c'est d'avoir un chantier qui puisse recevoir les plus grands bateaux du monde. Quelle vie Marcel? J'ai plus rien foutu depuis que je suis descendu de ces cabines. Bonjour chrie. Tu sais j'ai rflchi longuement  ton cadeau pour le voyage. Je l'ai choisi moi-mme. Tiens.
answer: Je peux l'ouvrir tout de suite?

question: Si tu veux.
answer: Oh Alain! C'est merveilleux! Tu me gtes. Je t'aime. Attends, je vais te montrer moi aussi ce que j'ai achet.

question: Encore du sho ping!
answer: Regarde mon pcheur de baleine... Tu sais il va faire trs froid cet hiver.

question: Avec a tu pourras le supporter.
answer: Mais non, c'est pour toi.

question: Pour moi?
answer: Regarde, il te va parfaitement bien!

question: Formidable! Sans toi je m'habillerais encore en docker. Je suis pass voir Franoise.
answer: Comment va-t-elle?

question: Je n'ai jamais vu tant de srenit. Elle m'a demand de tes nouvelles et si nous tions heureux.
answer: Le sommes nous?

question: Non! Ca a march?
answer: Au poil.

question: Sale boulot.
answer: Il fallait le faire.

question: Il est en retard.
answer: Je crois qu'on fait une erreur de le prendre avec nous.

question: Une erreur! C'est gnial. C'est une vedette  la tlvision. Il peut aller partout sans tre souponn... En plus il a besoin de fric.
answer: J'ai pas confiance en lui.

question: Our friend's name is SALVATORE BOCA. They call him SAL. He's a sweetheart. He once was picked up on suspicion of armed robbery. Tried to hold up Tiffany's on Fifth Avenue! In broad daylight! Could have got two-and-a-half to five, but they wouldn't prosecute. Also downtown they're sure he pulled off a contract on a guy named DeMarco.
answer: His old lady?

question: Her name's Angie... Fast filly... she drew a suspended for shoplifting a year ago... only a kid, nineteen according to the marriage license.
answer: Yeah, nineteen goin' on fifty. What else?

question: He's had the store a year an'a half... takes in a fast seven grand a year.
answer: So what's he doin' with two cars and hundred dollar tabs at the Chez?

question: The Merc's in his wife's name. Dodge belongs to his brother. Lou... he's a trainee at the Sanitation School on Ward's Island. Served time a couple of years ago, on assault and robbery raps.
answer: If that's not a drop or a pickup, I'll open a charge for you at Bloomingdale's.

question: Make it Alexander's, I like the toy department.
answer: Toy wit' this will ya.

question: There's about a hundred years' parole time in there night or day.
answer: They treat our boy like a king. Wonder why he don't bring his old lady?

question: There's your answer...
answer: Who's the greaser?

question: It's his father.
answer: I think we oughta burn him on suspicion.

question: Suspicion of what?
answer: Makin' wine in the basement. He looks like that wop stooge used to drive for the Fracisi brothers.

question: Lay off with that wop stuff, will you?
answer: That's the third time he come here this week. You got anything on the building?

question: The building's clean. I checked the tenant list -- Don Ameche, the actor lives there -- oh, and somebody else. Do the name Joel Weinstock ring a bell?
answer: You're kiddin'

question: No sir -- this is where Joel lives.
answer: He was the bank on that shipment outta Mexico three years ago.

question: So I've heard.
answer: Whatta you know -- he's takin' his wife out for a change. Got a job for me when this is over, Mrs. Levene? We have reason to believe it's a front for the biggest counterfeiting operation in the country. That's right. They're trying to steal the formula for Hershey bars -- What the hell am I drivin' for? I'm a first grade Detective. You're a second grade guinea.

question: I'm wounded. Oh, oh.
answer: What?

question: He's goin' to Ward's Island. We'll get spotted. What the hell's he goin' there?
answer: Maybe he's goin' to see his brother. Or could be another drop. I guess he gets a free ride. Hands on your heads. Popeye's here! What's my name? What? Ever pick your feet in Poughkeepsie? Milk shake anyone? Move ass when I tell you. Put it on the bar. All right, you three clowns step into those phone booths, you're goin' in. Go on. Stand in there till I'm ready for you. Everybody goes when the whistle blows.

question: I'm a dancer.
answer: All right, get up on that bar and dance.

question: What?
answer: Get up on the bar and show me how you work. If I like it you don't have to go in.

question: You're for real?
answer: Am I talkin' to you - I'm tellin' you to shut up and stand over there. Get up there.

question: I got no music!
answer: Fake it.

question: All right, that's enough, you're under arrest. What about you? Can you stand a toss?
answer: I'm clean.

question: You don't use shit?
answer: No.

question: Did I say you could move that hand -- I'm not gonna get stuck am I?
answer: No - no.

question: How's everything?
answer: Everything is everything.

question: How come there's nothing out there? That stuff is all milk.
answer: There's nothing around. Nobody's holding.

question: I got a name - Sal Boca, Brooklyn.
answer: Boca? Doesn't register.

question: Got a wife named Angie.
answer: No, nothing. There's only some talk.

question: What?
answer: Coming in this week, week after. Everybody going to get well.

question: Who brings it?
answer: Who knows?

question: Where do you want it?
answer: This side.

question: Where are you?
answer: Takin' care o' business, honey.

question: Takin' care o' business -- it's after midnight.
answer: You know I hadda meet some people tonight --

question: -- Well finish all your meetin' people and get back here now -- and bring a pizza with you.
answer: Where'm I goinna get a pizza this time o' night?

question: Well try, okay?
answer: I don't know where I'm gonna find a pizza joint open.

question: Sal --
answer: Yeah?

question: Don't forget anchovies.
answer: This broad's crazy!

question: The river at this point is the most dangerous on the East Coast. Years ago, hundreds of ships went down here.
answer: If this bridge were in Europe, it would be on every tourist's sight- seeing list.

question: Most New Yorkers never notice it - most Americans have never heard of it.
answer: Look how gracefully they conceived that arch. Like a bowstring. It was built from both ends. With no support in the middle. Beautiful.

question: I'm afraid the rest of Ward's Island isn't nearly as romantic - a pollution plant, a hospital, a training school for garbage men and that area over there, where the old cars are kept, prior to being processed for shipment to, among other places, The Charnier Shipping Company, of Marseilles, France.
answer: What is that old building?

question: Oh, it's been abandoned for years.
answer: What was it?

question: It was a crematorium.
answer: For garbage?

question: Allo... Salvatore...
answer: Who's this --

question: ... Salvatore?... Very well... you meet me RUSSO Wednesday at the hotel... French... It's a Frenchman...
answer: Good... good... great! DOYLE This is what we been waitin' CHARNIER for -- the stuff is here! Will I expect you? It's here! What time?

question: Twelve o'clock... yes...
answer: Yes --

question: Hey, Bo.
answer: Hiya, Jesus.

question: Can you use a new suit for Christmans?
answer: Whatta you got?

question: Whatta you?... a 44... 46?
answer: Where'd you get this fag shit?

question: This is what the tough guys are wearin'. You know I only steal from the best. It's Bonwit Teller.
answer: Pass.

question: Forty dollars -- was $250.
answer: Whyn't you get it dry cleaned and burned.

question: Whyn't you get it dry cleaned and burned.
answer: A big man could alluz beat a little man. That's why Wilt Chamberlain could murder Jim Brown if they ever fought. Chamberlain's seven foot tall, right? He's got a twelve-foot reach. It's geophysics. He's punchin' down on you with leverage. He cave your chest in. Blackjack Burns coulds been the greatest ever -- That's right, he couldn't fight legit. One night at the Garden about 1950, '51 -- he fought either Jake LaMotta or Gus Lesnevich, I think it was -- he took one o' those cream puff punches in the sixth -- the laziest left you ever seen -- missed him entirely. Down goes Blackjack without even workin' up a sweat and the whole Garden gets up in its feet and I swear to Christ, everybody starts singin' "Dance With Me Henry." What about you, Doyle? Who's the best fighter you ever seen?

question: Willie Mays. With a baseball bat! One swing! Knock your fuckin' head off.
answer: What ya doin' out so late? Hidin' from the cops?

question: I hear the health department is going to close this joint for selling dirty beer. I come by to help you carry out your money.
answer: They'll close you down if they ever get a look at those busted-valise broads you run with.

question: You want some eggs.
answer: Why not?

question: Hey, Mutch! You want bacon?
answer: Yeah!

question: Where the hell is it?
answer: Where the hell do you think it is, potato head? No wonder there's so many Mafia around. Ya couldn't find a Puerto Rican in Spanish Harlem. I got this little chick I'm tryin' to hit on. She's about 20, 21... I take her to Jilly's last night and she's tellin' me about how she wants to settle down one day, get married... I says, "Hey, this is 1971, baby, I'm just a dirty old man lookin' to score with some pussy."

question: Strike out, eh?
answer: Yeah. In the late innings. Ya look like a night's sleep wouldn't kill ya.

question: A piece of ass wouldn't kill me.
answer: When ya go back on?

question: Morning. Sometime.
answer: Whyn't ya stretch out on the pool table for a couple hours. The kid comes in at six will wake ya. A couple eggs and a beer is cheaper than keepin' a dog around the joint.

question: Whatta you got -- four more years, Walter?
answer: Three.

question: Christ, by the time you get out all this shit'll be legal.
answer: The judge gave you ten days on these. Klein and Mulderig will be sitting in for the Federals. Tell Doyle they'll make all the buys, and that they're to be kept informed of everything that goes down. You know Doyle, don't you Bill?

question: Whyn't you shove it up your ass! Popeye. Popeye.
answer: Yeah.

question: It's Cloudy. Open the door.
answer: I can't.

question: Why not?
answer: Let yourself in.

question: What the hell you got holding the door? What happened to you?
answer: The crazy kid handcuffed me to the bed. With my own cuffs.

question: You oughta get plastic covers for this stuff like I did - your scrapbook's a mess like everything else in your life.
answer: Gimme my pants. You got the warrant?

question: We also got Bill Mulderig and Phil Klein.
answer: What do we need those pricks for?

question: Because by actual count our bureau has exactly nine hundred eighteen dollars and fifty-four cents to make buys and Mulderig's Feds can get all of Uncle Sam's money he wants by just asking.
answer: Throw 'em in the bathroom, will you? How good are the warrants?

question: Sixty days. Here. Don't mention it. Hi! Drive carefully!
answer: Strictly small potatoes. You really know how to pick 'em, Doyle. Still wearing your gun on your ankle? Somebody told me the reason you did that was so's when you met a chick and rubbed against her she wouldn't know you were a cop. I said that was bullshit. It must be some kind of fast-draw gimmick or something.

question: Knock it off, Bill.
answer: He's gettin' too far ahead. You're gonna lose him.

question: Pour it in your ear.
answer: Yes sir?

question: That guy just walked in. What's his name?
answer: I'm sorry, I don't know who you mean.

question: He got off on six.
answer: We have four rooms and six suites on six. There's a man in almost every one of them.

question: Little shorter than me. Well- dressed. About forty-five or fifty with salt-and-pepper hair, a beard.
answer: There's nobody like that on six. Perhaps he's visiting a guest.

question: No, I figure he stays here. Where's your registration?
answer: There may be two... no, three who could fit it.

question: Names.
answer: A Mr. Paul Ganapolos, he's here alone.

question: Where from?
answer: Des Moines.

question: What's he do?
answer: Businessman. Owns a department store in Des Moines, I think. Mr. and Mrs. Alain Charnier, would be another. He's in shipping.

question: Yeh? Who else?
answer: And a Mr. Michael Lowenstein, I don't know what he does.

question: This Charnier guy. He's in shipping?
answer: I think so. But they're in Room 408. On the fourth floor.

question: Where's he from?
answer: Marseilles. That's in France.

question: Retail is not my end of the business. Are you telling me it's worth the half million?
answer: Sixty. By the time it gets down to nickel bags it's at least thirty-two million!

question: Thank you, Howard. Take what's left there with you and goodnight.
answer: I guess we got a deal, eh?

question: We got a test. A deal for half a million dollars, maybe.
answer: Joel, the man is in a hurry. He wants the bread and he wants to go back to France. He ain't gonna hang around and play games. He's one o' the shrewdest cats I ever run across.

question: What am I, a shmuck? What's the hurry? He could see a couple of shows and visit the top of the Empire State Building.
answer: Joel, don't jerk me. I spent a lot o' time settin' this one up.

question: So whatta you want a badge? It's your first major league game Sal. One thing I learned, move calmly, move cautiously. You'll never be sorry.
answer: I been damn careful up to now.

question: Which is why your phone lines are tapped and the Feds are crawlin' all over you like flies.
answer: I'm straight, Joel. They haven't got shit on me. Look, I'm tellin' you, he'll take the deal somewhere else.

question: He could go someplace else with his sixty kilos of heroin and see how easy it is to pull together a half million cash. He wouldn't find there was any hurry to do this kind of business.
answer: Look, the stuff is here. We could set up the switch in an hour. I'm tellin' you, Mr. Weinstock, he'll split if we don't move. This guy is everything they say he is.

question: It has been highly informative and a personal pleasure to see you again. Soon, probably in the Spring. Goodbye.
answer: Everything's smooth. Beautiful. I will need a few more days though, the boys think we oughta cool it for awhile -- make sure there's no heat.

question: You must take me for an imbecile. Why do you think I asked you to meet me in Washington? I haven't spent five minutes in New York City without the company of a gendarme.
answer: Look, I'll level with you -- I need a little more time -- I got to shift gears.

question: Are you having trouble raising the half million?
answer: Hell no -- my end is covered -- my associates just feel we ought to wait for a more opportune time to make the switch.

question: It has to be by the end of this week.
answer: Look, Mr. Charnier, you got to be reasonable.

question: It's your problem.
answer: It's yours too!

question: So nice to have seen you again.
answer: Look, darling, they sell these at the Smithsonian.

question: Are you sure it is dead?
answer: I'm going to put them on the cat.

question: That's a relief. You did find something for yourself, of course.
answer: Of course. But I am not going to tell you what it is until we are back in Marseilles.

question: Excuse me a moment, darling. I'm afraid they've become a bit... over-cautious. Our American friends.
answer: What happens to the schedule?

question: We must follow it.
answer: But will they?

question: I don't know. Boca is scared. He's not strong enough. He sees policemen in his soup.
answer: He is not wrong.

question: Mmmmm. That bastard who followed me on the subway, he's the eager one.
answer: Let me take him out.

question: There'll be someone else.
answer: What difference does it make? We'll be out of the country Friday.

question: The tracks racing by from the view of the train. We're approaching a station.
answer: Don't stop! Continue on to the next station! Touch the brake and I'll blow you in half.

question: Medium close shot of CROWD on train pushing toward the MOTORMAN's cab. They are upset over the missed stop. The CONDUCTOR seems to be the most annoyed.
answer: Get back.

question: He's in the brown Lincoln - foreign plates.
answer: Timezit?

question: Four.
answer: Same car.

question: Third time around.
answer: Let's him 'em. Up! Up, you sonofabitch! Of all the goddam cars they had to pick to steal hubcaps. A bunch of lousy little spic car thieves.

question: What are you looking for? Is it as big as an orange or an elephant's ass? I've been over every inch -- top to bottom. If you could give me a club -- to the size...
answer: What was the weight of the car when you got it, Irv?

question: 4,839 pounds.
answer: You're sure? The manufacturer's spec says it should weigh 4,719 pounds. This one's carrying roughly 120 extra pounds somewhere. When it was booked in at Marseilles it weighed the same. 120 pounds overweight. Jimmy has to be right.

question: I'm sorry, Mr. Devereaux, but we get reports on a couple hundred vehicles a night. Sometimes it's a little tough to keep track.
answer: You mean the car's here now?

question: Yeah -- fine -- it's okay -- not even a scratch. You're all set. Someone stole it right off the street, huh? You're gonna have to pay the tow away charge.
answer: I was told these things happen in New York -- but one never expects it.

question: Henri... Did you pick up the car?
answer: It is waiting for you in the garage.

question: Did they follow you?
answer: I wasn't looking.

question: Henri... I need one more favor from you. I know I am imposing...
answer: My friend, I am not sure about what is going on -- but for me, I am finished.

question: Not quite -- you are in it whether you like it or not. The police know you brought the car into the country. This makes you an accomplice.
answer: An accomplice to what?! What have you gotten me into, Alain? You asked me to do you a favor -- and I did what you asked -- but you've taken advantage of me. I have my reputation --

question: Calm down -- Henri! You must trust me -- this is an extremely complicated situation to which there is a simple solution if you do exactly what I tell you. It's worth more money to you.
answer: Goodbye.
